item.description:
(Detailed directions??? see below...)

So we all know what it’s like. Shopping. Shuffling thru endless sizes, styles, colors and fit. Going from one store to the next. Poking thru discount racks. Trying on one item after another. Leaving without. Going back. Trying again. And then... finding it!!! Getting excited. Dreaming about bringing it home. Wondering if it’s “right” for us. Imagining how it can’t be anything but “right” for us. Wondering if we can afford it. Deciding we can. Deciding we can’t. Buying it anyways. Thinking we just found the bargain of all bargains (regardless of the cost; regardless that it was found on the nobody-wants-me-rack). Bringing it home. Showing it to our friends. Committing to it. Trusting in it. Believing in it (even if our friends warned us not to). Only to have our hearts broken, because once home, we learn how NOT “right” it is. We learn that it’s NOT what we thought it was. It’s NOT what it claimed to be. It’s NOT anything but “wrong” for us. Sad-ness, mad-ness, and misery. Yes, it hurts, but we can’t blame it for everything, even if it did make promises that it didn’t keep. Even if it did say, “It’s just the way I am,” or “It’s how I was made,” or “It’s not you, it’s me.” We’re the ones who went shopping. We’re the ones who bought it. We’re to blame... right??? Partially??? HELL, NO!!!

Well, on Dec. 30th find out if the gear you got is “right” for you. Find out if it can keep you warm, if it can protect you, comfort you, support you… when things get tough. Find out if it’s what you hoped for. Find out if it’s what it claimed to be.

On Dec. 30th, join us on Mt. Monadnock, a sort of “gear counselor” for the winter hiker, a place to test the limits of your gear, without testing the limits of yourself (too severely anyways). Join us, even if your relationship w/ your gear is proven. Join us because you can.

The Hike:
We’ll start by planning a trip up the northwestern side of the mountain (map), beginning at the Dublin trailhead, we'll climb until we reach the summit, and then descend northeasterly via the Pumpelly Trail. Simple. A point to point hike, approximately 6.5 miles/6.5 hours long, that will require a car spot at the Pumpelly trailhead and a shuttle ride to the Dublin trailhead.

At the outset, the Dublin Trail is a comparatively moderate grade, cutting thru dense maple and spruce forest before narrowing, turning rocky and steep. As with most trails on Monadnock, there will be scrambling. Once at the peak, we’ll search out a crawl space or crevice to shelter ourselves from the bitter cold, only poking our heads out to confirm we’re at the top... and that we’re not the only fools to reach the summit. After a good bit of teeth chattering and laughter, we’ll begin our descent along the spine of the mountain, the Pumpelly Trail, taking in view after view, as we make our way below treeline. We’ll continue thru mixed forest along a progressively flattening trail to what car(s) we left behind.

As always, but especially in the winter, be prepared for changes of temperature and strong winds on the summit. Dress in layers and have wind/rain protection. Bring plenty of insulation, water, food, and something warm to drink. We will hike at a steady moderate pace, punctuated by short breaks so that we don’t cool off and become chilled. Finally, expect temps at or below freezing. Headlamps, MICROspikes and/or other traction devices will be required. Severe weather cancels this event. Pets are not permitted (park rules).

PS. Because this is winter, these plans are preliminary. Should conditions dictate, we may be required to hike up from the park’s headquarters, and should that be the case, I’m thinking we can ascend via the White Dot/White Cross trails, and return by way of the Pumpelly/Cascade trails, a most beautiful descent if there ever is one (TBD).

EQUIPMENT CHECKLIST

Cold Weather/Fall Essentials (required):
• Synthetic Quick-drying Pants
• Synthetic Quick-drying L/S Shirt
• Sturdy Hiking Boots/shoes (preferably waterproof)
• Synthetic/Wool Socks
• Insulated/Fleece Jacket
• Light/Mid-weight Insulating Layers (undershirt/underpants)
• Extra pair of Socks
• Hat/Gloves
• Rain/Soft Shell Jacket/Pants
• Water (2-3L)
• Headlamp/Flashlight
• Map/Compass/Whistle
• Lunch
• Snack/Energy Food (extra food)
• MICROspikes, STABLicers, ect... (a must when there's snow or ice on the trail)


the Remaining Essentials:
• Medications/First Aid Supplies
• Emergency Blanket (so small & light, there's hardly a reason not to have one in your pack)
• Fire (waterproof matches, lighter, starter)
• Repair Kit/Knife

Optional:
• Sunscreen/Sunglasses/Bug Repellant/Toiletries
• Light-weight Wind Jacket (if your insulated or rain jacket isn’t windproof)
• Hand Warmers
• Trekking Poles
• Gaiters
• Light-weight Emergency Shelter
• Camera/Binoculars

Important:
NO JEANS, NO SNEAKERS, NO COTTON CLOTHING (They get wet, They stay wet & They won’t keep you warm). ALSO, LET'S NOT UNDERESTIMATE ANYTHING, so come prepared for the worst: cold cold temps., wet weather, early darkness and lots of wind.

Directions:

From the NH Rt 101/Rt 137 intersection (map), north of Jaffrey, follow 101 west, for approx. 2 1/2 miles, past Upper Jaffrey Rd., turning left on to Lake/East Lake Road (be careful, Snow Hill Rd. shares the intersection w/ Lake Rd; Lake Rd. bares off to the right, Snow Hill to the left). Continue on Lake Rd. for approx. 1/2 mile; the Pumpelly trailhead is located on the left, opposite the southern shore of Dublin Lake. Parking is roadside, with no “established” spaces or trailhead marker; easiest parking is just beyond the trailhead.

Because parking is limited, we’ll spot as few cars as possible, and continue to the Dublin trailhead, approx. 2 miles further down Lake Rd. (which become Old Marlborough) to Old Troy Rd (map). Here we will begin our hike.

Additional Information:

Mount Monadnock: 3165 feet

Distance: approx. 6.5 miles
Elevation Gain (total): approx. 1800 ft
Exposure: Full @ the summit

Difficulty: Moderate/Strenuous
Pace: Moderate
Approx. Hike Time (including stops): 6:30+ hrs

Sunrise: 7:19 a.m.
Sunset: 4:23 p.m.

Approx. Temp. Hi: mid 30’s
Approx. Temp. Lo: mid 20’s

10-Day Weather Outlook:
http://www.weather.com/weather/tenday/USNH0116

7-Day National Weather Forecast (NOAA):
http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php

Current Trail Conditions:
http://monadnocktrails.com/weather.trails.php
http://www.nhstateparks.org/explore/state-parks/monadnock-trail-report.aspx


Liability Waiver:
As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at www.hikesafe.com; the leader(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify the leader(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
item.how_to_find_us: From the NH Rt 101/Rt 137 intersection, follow 101 west, for approx. 2.5 miles, turn left on to Lake/East Lake Road. Continue on Lake Rd. for approx. 1/2 mile; the Pumpelly trailhead is located on the left. [cell phone: 860-460-1500 ]
item.name: Back 2 Monadnock: Gear Counseling 201
